bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to James E. Peabody, January 28, 1942

div1.p: Hench provides details about progress on the Camp Lazear memorial and reports that he attended Emilie Lawrence Reed's birthday party. He also met with some of Lazear's relatives.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to James E. Peabody, January 28, 1942
div1.opener:
yf
January 28, 1942
Dr. James E. Peabody
281 Lowell Avenue
Newtonville, Massachusetts
My dear Doctor Peabody:
div1.p: Just a hasty note on my return after two weeks' absence in Washington.

I have heard from the owner of Camp Lazear who is willing to sell me
some more of the land and in the meantime some Cubans have become interested in
the project. It is entirely possible that the whole thing may be accepted as
a Cuban governmental project as Batista, the President, has become interested
and I understand a bill has been presented to the Cuban congress. I will keep
you informed.

Mrs. Hench and I had the honor and privilege of joining in a family
celebration on Mrs. Walter Reed's eighty-sixth birthday in Washington a few days
ago. She is very spry and alert. We also met some of Lazear's relatives who
took me to the old family home, in the attic of which I found one hundred thirty-
four letters of Lazear to his mother, including thirty-three sent from Cuba up to
the very day of his final illness. We also found some interesting old photographs
of his never published and some of his old school books. It was a thrilling
treasure hunt.

I spent several days searching through the National Archives in Washing-
ton and found much data which will in time find its way into my story. In the
meantime, please be assured of my thanks and I will keep you informed how matters
go.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
